title: 111_hr3133
content: The Act may be cited as the "Foreign Evidence Request Efficiency Act of 2009" and includes improvements to Title 18. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify court jurisdiction for issuing warrants in various subsections. Title 18 of the United States Code is amended to specify court jurisdiction for issuing warrants in various subsections, including federal courts and state courts with competent jurisdiction. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code specifies court jurisdiction for issuing warrants in federal courts and state courts with competent jurisdiction, including those acting on foreign assistance requests. The amendment to Title 18 of the United States Code specifies court jurisdiction for issuing warrants in federal courts and state courts with competent jurisdiction, including those acting on foreign assistance requests. It outlines the conditions under which foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions can be executed. Upon request from a foreign authority, a Federal judge may issue orders to assist in criminal investigations or prosecutions, including search warrants and orders for electronic communications. Upon request from a foreign authority, a Federal judge may issue orders for wire or electronic communications, records, pen registers, trap and trace devices, testimony, statements, or production of documents. Additionally, the judge may appoint a person to oversee the taking of testimony, statements, or production of documents in response to the foreign authority's application. Upon request from a foreign authority, a Federal judge may appoint a person to oversee the production of documents or other things, administer oaths, take testimony, and receive documents. Requests for execution of a foreign authority's request can be filed in the district where the person resides or where the documents are located. Upon request from a foreign authority, a Federal judge may appoint a person to oversee the production of documents or other things, administer oaths, take testimony, and receive documents. Requests for execution of a foreign authority's request can be filed in the district where the person resides or where the documents are located. The search warrant limitation states that an application for a search warrant from a foreign authority must be filed in the district where the place or person to be searched is located. A Federal judge may issue a search warrant under this section only if the foreign offense involves conduct that, if committed in the United States. The section discusses the service of orders or warrants issued under this law in the United States, without precluding foreign authorities from seeking assistance in criminal investigations. Definitions for 'Federal judge' and 'attorney for the Government' are provided. The curr_chunk defines 'foreign authority' for the purposes of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure. The curr_chunk pertains to foreign requests for assistance in criminal investigations and prosecutions.
